In this exercise, we will discuss the traits of callable bonds.

**Let's get started!**

We will start by explaining what a callable bond is. A callable bond is a type of bond that allows the issuer of the bond to retain the privilege of redeeming the bond at some point before the bond reaches its date of maturity. It **provides the issuer of the bond with the right, but not the obligation, to redeem the bond before its maturity date.** Such a feature is called call feature. To protect against unfavorable interest rate changes, the issuer utilizes the call feature. Bonds can be purchased back using the call feature and replaced with new bonds bearing a lower interest rate if interest rates fall.

As a result, the price of a callable bond should be equal to the price of an identical noncallable bond minus the value of the call feature: $$\text{Price}_\text{callable} = \text{Price}_\text{noncallable} - \text{Call Feature Value} \tag{1}$$

In our case, we are given two noncallable bonds which are similar to the callable bond . We can therefore use these two bonds to find the value of the callable bond . Let x denote the money we are investing. We will invest X money into the first noncallable bond and the rest of the money (1 - X) into the third noncallable bond. This weighted sum of two investments will give us a combination that has the same value as our second, callable bond: $$\begin{aligned} \text{Bond Value}_2 &= 6.25 \times X + \text{Bond Value}_3\times(1 – X) \\[10pt] 8.25 &= 6.25 \times X+ 12. 0\times(1 – X) \\[10pt] X &= 0.68181 \end{aligned}$$

This combination of bonds should have the same value as the callable bond (excluding the value of the call feature ). So, we will use the ratios we calculated in the last step, and multiply them by the current bond prices. The sum of these products is the implied bond value of the callable bond: $$\begin{aligned} \text{IBV}&=(\text{Current Price}_1×0.682)+(\text{Current Price}_3 ×(1−0.682)) \\[10pt] &= (106.31250\times0.682)+ 134.78125 \times (1−0.682)) \\[10pt] &= 115.4730 \end{aligned}$$

Finally, we'll use the Eq.$(1)$ to calculate the value of the. The call feature value is the difference between the implied bond value and the actual bond price, as shown by Eq.$(1)$ : $$\begin{aligned} \text{Call Feature Value} &= \text{Price}_\text{noncallable} - \text{Price}_\text{callable}\\[10pt] &= 115.4730 - 103.50 \\[10pt] &= 11.9730 \end{aligned}$$

**Let's recap what we have learned in this exercise!** First, we explained the key terms of this exercise - the callable bond and it's important characteristic known as call feature . Then, by using the other two similar, noncallable bonds we calculated the implied bond value for our callable bond . Finally, we calculated the value of the call feature .
